articles.headline: Bloomberg Takes Steps Into 2020 Race, Signaling Unconventional Campaign Strategy
articles.snippet: The former New York City mayor submitted paperwork to enter the presidential primary in Alabama, which has the first filing deadline, indicating he would pursue a risky strategy of skipping all four traditional early-state contests.
articles.abstract: The former New York City mayor submitted paperwork to enter the presidential primary in Alabama, which has the first filing deadline, indicating he would pursue a risky strategy of skipping all four traditional early-state contests.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg disrupted the Democratic presidential field on Friday as he took his first steps into the 2020 race, unnerving supporters of Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and prompting Senators Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders to accuse Mr. Bloomberg of seeking to buy the presidency.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Katie Glueck

articles.headline: With Medical Bills Skyrocketing, More Hospitals Are Suing for Payment
articles.snippet: As deductibles and co-pays grow, insured patients owe a larger share of their medical bills. More and more are being taken to court.
articles.abstract: As deductibles and co-pays grow, insured patients owe a larger share of their medical bills. More and more are being taken to court.
articles.lead_paragraph: WISE, Va. — When a judge hears civil cases at the courthouse in this southwest Virginia town two days a month, many of the lawsuits have a common plaintiff: the local hospital, Ballad Health, suing patients over unpaid medical bills.
articles.byline: By Sarah Kliff

articles.headline: McKinsey Faces Criminal Inquiry Over Bankruptcy Case Conduct
articles.snippet: Prosecutors are examining the consulting company’s behavior in at least two bankruptcy cases.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors are examining the consulting company’s behavior in at least two bankruptcy cases.
articles.lead_paragraph: McKinsey & Company, the elite consulting firm that advises many of the world’s largest and most powerful institutions, is facing a federal criminal investigation of its conduct advising bankrupt companies, according to five people familiar with the matter.
articles.byline: By Mary Williams Walsh and Emily Flitter

articles.headline: How Should a Billionaire Behave in Public? A Run for President Is One Option
articles.snippet: Michael Bloomberg may join a 2020 field where some leading candidates are railing against wealth like his. It’s complicated.
articles.abstract: Michael Bloomberg may join a 2020 field where some leading candidates are railing against wealth like his. It’s complicated.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is probably never a bad time to be a billionaire. But this, at least, is an especially complicated one.
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer

articles.headline: Facebook Takes Down Breitbart Posts That Claimed to Name Whistle-Blower
articles.snippet: Facebook, which included Breitbart in its new news feed just two weeks ago, said it was removing any mention of the purported whistle-blower’s name.
articles.abstract: Facebook, which included Breitbart in its new news feed just two weeks ago, said it was removing any mention of the purported whistle-blower’s name.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facebook has taken down articles posted by the far-right site Breitbart that purported to identify the whistle-blower who triggered the impeachment inquiry of President Trump, just two weeks after including the site in the lineup of publishers whose work would be featured in a new news product.
articles.byline: By Marc Tracy

articles.headline: Bolton Said to Know of ‘Many Relevant Meetings’ on Ukraine, but Will Not Testify
articles.snippet: A lawyer for John R. Bolton said he had information to share with impeachment investigators. But, so far, he will not defy the White House.
articles.abstract: A lawyer for John R. Bolton said he had information to share with impeachment investigators. But, so far, he will not defy the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — John R. Bolton, President Trump’s former national security adviser, knows about “many relevant meetings and conversations” connected to a pressure campaign on Ukraine that House impeachment investigators have not yet been informed of, his lawyer told lawmakers on Friday.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Fandos, Michael D. Shear and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Scandinavian Wine? A Warming Climate Tempts Entrepreneurs
articles.snippet: Hotter weather is fueling efforts to create a commercial wine industry in Denmark, Norway and Sweden.
articles.abstract: Hotter weather is fueling efforts to create a commercial wine industry in Denmark, Norway and Sweden.
articles.lead_paragraph: SKAERSOGAARD, Denmark — On a mild autumn morning, Sven Moesgaard climbed a sunbathed hill and inspected an undulating expanse of neatly planted vines. A picking crew was harvesting tons of hardy Solaris grapes that he would soon turn into thousands of bottles of crisp white and sparkling Danish wine.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman

articles.headline: How Voters Turned Virginia From Deep Red to Solid Blue
articles.snippet: A new kind of suburbanization is sweeping through politics, from Richmond to Atlanta, Houston, Denver and elsewhere, and Democrats are starting to breach Republicans’ firewalls in elections.
articles.abstract: A new kind of suburbanization is sweeping through politics, from Richmond to Atlanta, Houston, Denver and elsewhere, and Democrats are starting to breach Republicans’ firewalls in elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOUTH RIDING, Va. — Not long ago, this rolling green stretch of Northern Virginia was farmland. Most people who could vote had grown up here. And when they did, they usually chose Republicans.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise, Robert Gebeloff and Lauren Leatherby

articles.headline: Spyware Maker NSO Promises Reform but Keeps Snooping
articles.snippet: Recent revelations in India show that the threat from the company’s spyware to activists and journalists isn’t limited to autocratic regimes.
articles.abstract: Recent revelations in India show that the threat from the company’s spyware to activists and journalists isn’t limited to autocratic regimes.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — Bela Bhatia, a human rights lawyer in the Indian state of Chhattisgarh, is accustomed to surveillance. She works in a region prone to both guerrilla violence and government reprisals, and the authorities do not like many of her clients.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: The Last Days of Legal Cockfighting in Puerto Rico
articles.snippet: Cockfighting will soon be outlawed, an overdue ban in the eyes of animal welfare advocates. But some Puerto Ricans maintain it is part of their culture.
articles.abstract: Cockfighting will soon be outlawed, an overdue ban in the eyes of animal welfare advocates. But some Puerto Ricans maintain it is part of their culture.
articles.lead_paragraph: VEGA BAJA, P.R. — Hiram Figueroa rears roosters to fight, a Puerto Rican tradition from the time of the Spanish colonists that he learned as a teenager half a century ago and later taught his son. Together, they exercise their birds, clip their feathers and give them delicate sponge baths.
articles.byline: By Patricia Mazzei and Erika P. Rodriguez

articles.headline: Child Abusers Run Rampant as Tech Companies Look the Other Way
articles.snippet: Though platforms bar child sexual abuse imagery on the web, criminals are exploiting gaps. Victims are caught in a living nightmare, confronting images again and again.
articles.abstract: Though platforms bar child sexual abuse imagery on the web, criminals are exploiting gaps. Victims are caught in a living nightmare, confronting images again and again.
articles.lead_paragraph: Though platforms bar child sexual abuse imagery on the web, criminals are exploiting gaps. Victims are caught in a living nightmare, confronting images again and again.
articles.byline: By Michael H. Keller and Gabriel J.X. Dance

articles.headline: How the State Dept.’s Dissenters Incited a Revolt, Then a Rallying Cry
articles.snippet: Shock, anger and sadness are giving way to pride among career diplomats that they are defending American ideals and holding the Trump administration accountable.
articles.abstract: Shock, anger and sadness are giving way to pride among career diplomats that they are defending American ideals and holding the Trump administration accountable.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of Marie Yovanovitch’s public impeachment inquiry hearing.
articles.byline: By Michael Crowley, Lara Jakes and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: ‘I’d Consider Anybody’: Democrats Like Their 2020 Candidates, and Yet ...
articles.snippet: Michael R. Bloomberg is poised to enter a race that has many voters anxious and searching for the perfect candidate. But do they need yet one more option?
articles.abstract: Michael R. Bloomberg is poised to enter a race that has many voters anxious and searching for the perfect candidate. But do they need yet one more option?
articles.lead_paragraph: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa — Jackie Wellman worries that Senators Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren are too liberal to defeat President Trump, thinks Mayor Pete Buttigieg of South Bend, Ind., may be too inexperienced and, while she is fond of Joseph R. Biden Jr., she is also uneasy about his tendency to misspeak. “I am worried about the top four candidates because they all have issues,” said Ms. Wellman, a 54-year-old Iowa caucusgoer from West Des Moines who likes Senator Amy Klobuchar.
articles.byline: By Sydney Ember and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Warren Would Take Billionaires Down a Few Billion Pegs
articles.snippet: Elizabeth Warren’s tax proposals would significantly curb the gigantic fortunes of America’s richest families over time.
articles.abstract: Elizabeth Warren’s tax proposals would significantly curb the gigantic fortunes of America’s richest families over time.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Yes, billionaires will have to pay a little more,” Senator Elizabeth Warren said of the revised tax package she introduced recently, “six cents on each dollar.”
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen

articles.headline: Boeing Aims to Move Victim Lawsuits Abroad, but C.E.O. Says He Is Unaware
articles.snippet: Boeing lawyers have publicly disclosed the strategy to transfer the cases out of the U.S., which could save the company millions.
articles.abstract: Boeing lawyers have publicly disclosed the strategy to transfer the cases out of the U.S., which could save the company millions.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Boeing’s chief executive was asked by Congress last month if the company was working to get lawsuits related to the deadly crash of Lion Air Flight 610 transferred from the United States to Indonesia, where the accident occurred, he pleaded ignorance.
articles.byline: By David Gelles

articles.headline: What Joe Biden Actually Did in Ukraine
articles.snippet: The aims and the aftermath of a legacy project that underscores Mr. Biden’s years of diplomacy — but has been swallowed by the subplot of his son and a Ukrainian gas company.
articles.abstract: The aims and the aftermath of a legacy project that underscores Mr. Biden’s years of diplomacy — but has been swallowed by the subplot of his son and a Ukrainian gas company.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Russia invaded Ukraine in early 2014, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. pressed President Barack Obama to take decisive action, and fast, to make Moscow “pay in blood and money” for its aggression. The president, a Biden aide recalled, was having none of it.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush and Kenneth P. Vogel

articles.headline: Netflix Was Only the Start: Disney Streaming Service Shakes an Industry
articles.snippet: With the arrival of Disney Plus on Tuesday, a growing medium rises to dominance.
articles.abstract: With the arrival of Disney Plus on Tuesday, a growing medium rises to dominance.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — He had a toe in the water.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Bolivian Leader Evo Morales Steps Down
articles.snippet: A leftist who had served longer than any other current head of state in Latin America, Mr. Morales lost his grip on power amid violent protests set off by a disputed election.
articles.abstract: A leftist who had served longer than any other current head of state in Latin America, Mr. Morales lost his grip on power amid violent protests set off by a disputed election.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Evo Morales of Bolivia, who came to power more than a decade ago as part of a leftist wave sweeping Latin America, resigned on Sunday after unrelenting protests by an infuriated population that accused him of undermining democracy to extend his rule.
articles.byline: By Ernesto Londoño

articles.headline: The F.B.I.’s New Approach to Combating Domestic Terrorism: Straight Talk
articles.snippet: Anticipating a surge in racist and hate-fueled attacks during the 2020 race, officials are speaking more frankly about politically motivated violence.
articles.abstract: Anticipating a surge in racist and hate-fueled attacks during the 2020 race, officials are speaking more frankly about politically motivated violence.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKWOOD VILLAGE, Ohio — As a group of prominent black pastors listened, the top federal prosecutor in northern Ohio, Justin E. Herdman, spoke recently at Mount Zion church about the prospect that a gunman could target one of their congregations.
articles.byline: By Adam Goldman

articles.headline: How Bad Is China’s Debt? A City Hospital Is Asking Nurses for Loans
articles.snippet: The city of Ruzhou spent big, then used its health care workers to raise money, as local governments look for ways to keep the economy going.
articles.abstract: The city of Ruzhou spent big, then used its health care workers to raise money, as local governments look for ways to keep the economy going.
articles.lead_paragraph: RUZHOU, China — When the call came for local doctors and nurses to step up for their troubled community, the emergency wasn’t medical. It was financial.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Cao Li

articles.headline: Close Election in Kentucky Was Ripe for Twitter, and an Omen for 2020
articles.snippet: As hyperpartisan activists, trolls and bots spread unfounded claims of voter fraud, a contested governor’s race is a preview of what many fear for the presidential election.
articles.abstract: As hyperpartisan activists, trolls and bots spread unfounded claims of voter fraud, a contested governor’s race is a preview of what many fear for the presidential election.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few hours after polls closed in Kentucky last Tuesday, a Twitter user writing under the handle @Overlordkraken1 posted a message to his 19 followers saying he had “just shredded a box of Republican mail-in ballots.”
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg and Nick Corasaniti

articles.headline: Evo Morales of Bolivia Accepts Asylum in Mexico
articles.snippet: The former president, who faced weeks of protest, said he had been forced out in a “coup.” He leaves Bolivia in a power vacuum, with politicians scrambling to form a caretaker government.
articles.abstract: The former president, who faced weeks of protest, said he had been forced out in a “coup.” He leaves Bolivia in a power vacuum, with politicians scrambling to form a caretaker government.
articles.lead_paragraph: LA PAZ, Bolivia — Evo Morales, the former president of Bolivia who resigned under pressure from street protests and the military, was granted asylum in Mexico on Monday, departing from the country at a time when it is deeply polarized and leaderless.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: How Russia Meddles Abroad for Profit: Cash, Trolls and a Cult Leader
articles.snippet: Madagascar has little obvious strategic value for the Kremlin or the global balance of power. But Russians were there during an election, offering bribes, spreading disinformation and recruiting an apocalyptic cult leader.
articles.abstract: Madagascar has little obvious strategic value for the Kremlin or the global balance of power. But Russians were there during an election, offering bribes, spreading disinformation and recruiting an apocalyptic cult leader.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANTANANARIVO, Madagascar — The Russians were hard to miss. They appeared suddenly last year in Madagascar’s traffic-snarled capital, carrying backpacks stuffed with cash and campaign swag decorated with the name of Madagascar’s president.
articles.byline: By Michael Schwirtz and Gaelle Borgia

articles.headline: How the Trump Administration Eroded Its Own Legal Case on DACA
articles.snippet: When the Supreme Court hears arguments on Tuesday, the administration’s attempts to end the program protecting “Dreamers” could rest on a top aide’s actions in 2017.
articles.abstract: When the Supreme Court hears arguments on Tuesday, the administration’s attempts to end the program protecting “Dreamers” could rest on a top aide’s actions in 2017.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Attorney General Jeff Sessions appeared before news cameras at the Justice Department in early September 2017 to announce that President Trump was ending deportation protections for young undocumented immigrants, he knew the administration had left itself more legally vulnerable than it should have.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Adam Liptak

articles.headline: Ugly From the Outset: Hong Kong’s Day of Widespread Violence
articles.snippet: A police officer shot a young protester, while a man arguing with protesters was set on fire. Both were fighting for their lives.
articles.abstract: A police officer shot a young protester, while a man arguing with protesters was set on fire. Both were fighting for their lives.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Hong Kong was a city on edge on Monday following escalating violence, in which one demonstrator was shot point blank by a police officer and one man was doused with a flammable liquid and set on fire after he scolded protesters.
articles.byline: By Mike Ives, Elaine Yu and Edward Wong

articles.headline: Europe Is Toughest on Big Tech, Yet Big Tech Still Reigns
articles.snippet: There is a lot to learn from mistakes that the Continent’s regulators have made, say consumer groups, lawyers and rival companies.
articles.abstract: There is a lot to learn from mistakes that the Continent’s regulators have made, say consumer groups, lawyers and rival companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Richard Stables should have felt vindicated when the European Union announced a $2.7 billion fine in 2017 against Google for breaking antitrust laws. He had raised alarms about the search giant’s power for years.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano
